 1. URBANIZATION AND THE ENVIRONMENT A. URBANIZATION: GROWTH AND IMPACT 1.1 National economic policies and resource allocation practices in China sought until the mid-1980s to limit urban population growth and restrain expenditures on essential urban infrastructure. Urban population expansion was controlled through resident permits and grain rationing. With accelerating economic growth and a relaxation of control on migration, urban growth rates averaged 4.2 percent through the 1980s, then jumped to nearly 6 percent with the economic boom that started in 1992. Currently, the urban population is increasing at about 5 percent a year, and urban GDP is growing at an annual 15 percent. Although the overall urbanization rate is still only 28 percent, in absolute terms, China now has the world's largest urban population-340 million "permanent" residents and another 70 million "temporary" residents in 600 cities and 15,000 statutory towns. Thirty-two cities have more than I million residents within the city boundaries, and another 30 cities each have more than 500,000 residents. Given these trends, the majority of China's population-an estimated 700 million persons-will live in existing or emerging urban areas by the year 2010. 1.2 Growing urban population and industrialization are causing widespread pollution in China, and environmental problems have become a central issue in Chinese cities.' Industrial production, particularly by outdated plants and fuel systems, has generated serious urban pollution problems of all types but particularly water pollution that directly affects human health. Many important water resources, which are already scarce in most regions, have been seriously threatened. Industrial wastewater is the predominant source of pollution, in some cases contributing up to 70 to 80 percent of the pollutant load. During 1984-92, only about 13 percent of the estimated 25 billion tons of industrial wastewater annually discharged throughout China was treated, and often only to the extent of pretreatment. After treatment, only about half of this water met effluent discharge standards. While industrial wastewater discharge has been kept constant through water use quotas and water recycling requirements, municipal (domestic and commercial) wastewater discharges have increased rapidly, from about 7 billion tons in 1984 to about 13 billion tons in 1992. Municipal wastewater treatment capacity can currently handle only about 4.5 percent of municipal wastewater flows, while industrial pretreatment raises overall treatment rates to 17 percent. 1 For a detailed discussion please see "China: Environmental Strategy Paper" (Report No. 9669-CHA, April 1992); and "China: Urban Environmental Service Managemenf' (Report No. 13073-CHA, December 1994).

URBAN ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES: CURRENT ARRANGEMENTS AND ISSUES Organization and Financing 1.3 Urban environmental services, including water supply, wastewater collection and treatment systems, and solid waste collection and treatment, are handled by city Construction Commissions, which oversee the municipal bureaus and companies directly responsible for providing services. The Commissions are typically among the largest and most powerful of the municipal administrative bodies. The Central Government confines itself to providing guidance and interregional coordination. The Ministry of Construction sets physical and financial performance standards for the services, appraises major investments in the sector to help guarantee adherence to standards, and provides guidance in implementing new management approaches. The National Environmental Protection Agency (NEPA) similarly provides technical and policy guidance on environmental issues and implementation of the national environmental protection system, comprising a broad set of control instruments administered by local environmental protection bureaus. 1.4 Local governments have great latitude to manage their own affairs and, subject to tax-sharing arrangements and annual consultation with the central authorities, are largely free to allocate resources according to their own priorities. Those resources are largely derived from local taxes and the earnings of municipal enterprises, supplemented to some extent by Central Government investments and (increasingly scarce) grants. Even on technical and regulatory matters, local agencies are free to adapt national guidelines and standards to their specific circumstances. Issues 1.5 While progress in decentralization is important for effective, efficient urban environmental management, the adequacy and sustainability of the current system is severely limited by the need to improve: (a) arrangements for mobilizing financial resources; (b) institutional capacity to meet the growing challenges faced; and (c) environmental policies and institutions to maximize pollution prevention and exert effective oversight and regulatory enforcement. 1.6 Financing. China subscribes to the "polluter-pays" principle of environmental management. As is common in other countries, a combination of administrative sanctions and economic incentives is used to induce desired behavior. However, China has consistently underpriced water supplies and wastewater treatment. The major policy problem identified in the Bank's study, China: Urban Environmental Service Management (Report No. 13073-CHA, December 1994) was the dependence on municipal budget transfers to fund environmental services and the failure to charge, or charge adequately, for those services. Although cities have long charged for water delivery, residential wastewater charges are virtually unknown, while enterprise charges have been rare, and where collected, fall far below operating needs. An important consequence of this failure to charge adequate user fees is that service investment programs have failed to meet goals due to lack of finance. The Ministry of Construction estimates that two thirds of the municipal
 -3 - wastewater treatment plants either do not operate, or operate far below capacity, due to lack of funds. And, when users do not have to pay, they have no incentive to reduce waste volumes. This creates the need for larger service systems when they are provided. Evidence of that comes from analysis of water and wastewater company finances and from studies that have shown industrial wastewater streams to be highly dilute compared to those from similar industries elsewhere in the world. Underpricing leads not only to excess demand and needlessly large water and wastewater streams, but also to reduced removal efficiencies experienced when treating dilute wastewaters. Thus, greater reliance on user charges would induce resource conservation, and create a more dependable income stream for system operation and maintenance; Bank analysis indicates that such charges would be affordable. 1.7 Commercialization. Institutionally, there is a need to introduce commercial practices for all urban environmental services. Currently, water systems tend to be run by financially autonomous enterprises, while wastewater collection and treatment as well as solid waste collection and disposal are managed by city government bureaus that see their role as providing welfare services. Managing bureaus do not depreciate fixed assets, so they cannot identify the true cost of service provision. Nor do their accounting practices provide managers with the financial tools needed for efficient management. Financially autonomous wastewater agencies need to be established, using enterprise accounting rules that allow them to set tariffs which at least fully recover costs. Environmental sanitation bureaus handling solid wastes need to introduce cost accounting techniques that permit them to identify the cost of operations so that they can charge those full costs to the commercial and industrial users of their services. 1.8 Regulation. NEPA is the lead agency for environmental management in China, with authority to draft national regulations and other aspects of environmental policy and to interpret national environmental regulations and standards. However, it lacks implementation authority, a power left to local governments and environmental protection bureaus (EPBs). Provincial EPBs coordinate local policies, while municipal, urban district and county EPBs bear the main burden of enforcement for both national and provincial regulations. Since local governments usually own the major enterprises within their boundaries, pressures may be exerted on the EPBs to relax regulation or fee collection in the interest of employment and profits. Also, enterprises operating on the periphery of cities may have a large impact on municipal environmental quality, yet fall outside municipal control. Furthermore, one of the main regulatory instruments, pollution levy fees chargeable against waste streams with pollutant concentrations above permitted levels, are typically set below the marginal cost of effluent treatment, which encourages enterprises to pay the fee rather than address the problem. 1.9 The proposed project continues efforts under the FY87 Bank Group-assisted sewerage project, the Shanghai Sewerage Project-SSPI (Loan 2794/Credit 1779-CHA), to address the financial and institutional factors limiting effective wastewater management in Shanghai, China's largest city, while the FY94 Bank-assisted Shanghai

BANK GROUP SECTOR STRATEGY 1.10 As indicated in the China Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) presented to the Board in June 1995, Bank Group support for urban environmental management in China follows directly from two of our four areas of concentration in the country-enhancing enviromnental protection and alleviating infrastructure bottlenecks. Our support, designed in close collaboration with our Chinese counterparts, covers both the regulatory and service provision aspects of this increasingly important sector. On the regulatory side, the China. Environmental Strategy Paper led to an Environmental Technical Assistance Project (Credit 2522-CHA), which assists NEPA to find more efficient regulatory methods, improve staff capabilities and bolster environmental monitoring. That project complements Bank-administered, Japanese Government-financed technical assistance to NEPA in other critical areas. 1.11 Service delivery as well as enhanced regulatory capacity at the local level are supported under five ongoing urban environrnental projects in eight cities, which incorporate policy, financing and organizational strategies for improved environmental regulation and service delivery at the provincial and municipal levels. Another four ongoing investment projects involving 12 cities include related issues such as municipal water supply and sanitation. Most of these projects focus on China's largest cities- Shanghai, Beijing and Tianjin-and those located primarily in the wealthier northeastern and coastal provinces. Environmental pressures remain very high in these areas and cooperation will continue, for example, under the proposed Second Shanghai Sewerage Project (SSPII) and the Shandong Environment Project now being prepared. These initiatives are balanced by a move to assist inland and poorer areas, as exemplified by the recently approved Hubei Urban Environmental Project (Loan 3966/Credit 2799-CHA), for a medium-income province in central China, as well as projects being prepared by the very poor provinces of Yunnan and Guangxi, which will further test the feasibility of policy and institutional solutions. 1.12 Our strategy for Shanghai responds in general to current and previous CAS objectives and in particular to the recommendations of a 1986 study on an optimal wastewater management strategy for Shanghai and Shanghai's Environmental Master Plan prepared in 1995 with Australian assistance. SSPI supported wastewater system investments in the northern part of the city, complemented by establishment of the Shanghai Sewerage Company-SSC [reorganized in December 1995 as the Shanghai Municipal Sewerage Company, Ltd.-SMSC (para. 4.1)], a comprehensive training program for SSC staff, and four studies-of SSC's future organizational and staffing needs, appropriate tariffs, water resource management in the Huangpu River Basin, and economic approaches to rehabilitating the existing combined sewerage system. SEP provides complementary support focused on improving and protecting drinking water quality and controlling pollution. Key project features include construction of a major
 -5 - raw water supply intake, improvements in the water distribution network, institutional strengthening, enhanced environmental monitoring and preparation of a water supply master plan. The proposed second sewerage project emphasizes institutional development, including organizational strengthening of SMSC, further financial capacity building, and investments in the southem part of the city's wastewater management system. On completion, these projects will have: (a) established economically sustainable and financially viable water and wastewater pricing policies and institutions; (b) initiated Shanghai's long-term wastewater management strategy and operation of improved and affordable water and wastewater services; and (c) launched a phased strategy to arrest environmental degradation of the Huangpu River and the surrounding watercourses, enabling regional economic growth consistent with the vision of the Shanghai government. 1.13 The Bank's assistance to Shanghai in addressing these problems is particularly important because of Shanghai's role as a leader in urban environmental management and protection throughout China. Shanghai's environmental problems typify those in Chinese cities, and the city is a development model for other Chinese urban areas. Successful completion of the wastewater system would give impetus to that aspect of our sector policy dialogue, a crucial element of which seeks adequate pricing for and the financial sustainability of urban services. Though a difficult issue for the Shanghai Municipal Government (SMG) in the current inflationary environment, the 30 percent water tariff increase already implemented under SEP signaled a willingness to deal effectively with this challenge. The higher water tariffs agreed under that project would further moderate water demand and hence wastewater flows, increase revenue, and enable more efficient urban services management. The approval in July 1995 of average wastewater tariff increases in Shanghai of some 100 percent through the proposed project would promote Government national policy and Bank Group efforts to introduce these practices in other provinces where projects are being prepared for Bank assistance.

URBAN GROWTH AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT IN SHANGHAI 2.1 Shanghai Municipality (SM), one of three provincial-level cities in China, is the country's largest contiguous urban center, with a permanent, registered population approaching 13 million and a temporary population of about 3 million. The city is China's most important industrial base, and the major center of commerce, trade, finance and science. Shanghai's per capita gross domestic project (GDP) in 1993 was Y 11,205 (almost four times the national average, 2.3 times that of Guangdong, and 44 percent higher than in Beijing). After decades of neglect and comparatively low economic growth, economic and institutional reforms during the 1990s have allowed the city to recapture its former importance in China (and the world) and have led to real annual GDP growth rates of almost 15 percent in the first half of the decade. From 1990 to 1993, Shanghai's per capita GDP grew by 36 percent in real terms. 2.2 Over 78 percent of Shanghai's population is concentrated in the municipality's urban zone of 254 square kilometers (kn2). The greater Shanghai area also includes nine rural counties and covers 6,340 km . Counting temporary residents, at least half of whom are rural migrants, Shanghai has an urban population density of just under 50,000 inhabitants per km., making it one of the world's most densely populated cities. Although natural population growth rates have declined markedly in recent years (to minus 0.08 percent in 1993 in the urban area), Shanghai's population is expected to continue to grow to at least 17 million people by the year 2000, largely due to a growing number of rural migrants seeking employment in China's premier commercial center. 2.3 Shanghai has regional importance as well, by being situated at the mouth of the Changjiang (Yangtze River) and thus at the heart of the Yangtze Delta Economic Region (YDER), which includes Jiangsu, Zhejiang and Anhui Provinces (see IBRD Map 27376). The YDER has a population of 193 million-the same as Indonesia's-and is the principal economic producer in China, providing 22.1 percent of GDP and 39.4 percent of secondary sector GDP. 2.4 Demographic and economic trends in Shanghai and the YDER have major implications in terms of demand for municipal infrastructure and the spatial distribution of this demand. Rapid urban growth is causing increased domestic and industrial wastewater discharges, new suburban growth poles are attracting inner-city residents whose urban communities are being redeveloped, and job opportunities are attracting large inflows of migrant workers. Planning for Shanghai's environmental infrastructure must cater for all of these trends.
 - 7 - B. WATER RESOURCE DEGRADATION IN SHANGHAI 2.5 Shanghai, located where the Changjiang joins the East China Sea, has numerous watercourses and canals flowing through the municipal area. These waters mainly drain to the Huangpu River, which passes through the city center and flows into the Changjiang. The water courses are interconnected and tidal, experiencing several hours a day of reverse flows during high tides. The waterways serve many functions, among them receiving stormwater and industrial wastewater flows, and acting as major transport corridors. The Shanghai Municipal Waterworks Company (SMWC) supplies the city with water abstracted principally from the Huangpu River, which is then treated and pumped into an extensive distribution network. Industry also abstracts water from the River for its own uses. 2.6 Still, low wastewater collection and treatment levels in Shanghai have resulted in substantial pollutant loads entering the surrounding waterways, causing major environmental and ecological damage to the water resources. This poses significant health risks and restricts economic growth. Fish cannot live in the lower Huangpu and tributary streams, and shellfish downstream of the city carry very high pathogen levels that result in illness when eaten by humans. The river system tides drive pollutants upstream as far as Shanghai's drinking water treatment plant intakes. Not only has this forced massive investment to relocate these intakes to safer areas, but it has also considerably increased water treatment costs and given rise to a high and costly risk of emergency water treatment shutdowns. Inevitably, domestic sources of pollutants will further increase over the next few years, as living standards rise and the 50 percent of Shanghai's citizens, who currently rely on yard taps and nightsoil buckets (emptied daily to holding tanks) for indoor sanitation, relocate to housing with flush toilets and indoor taps that allow the use of washing machines and other conveniences. C. SHANGHAI'S WASTEWATER MANAGEMENT PROGRAM Wastewater Management Strategy 2.7 About a decade ago, both the central government and SMG recognized the serious backlog in the provision of basic and essential urban environmental services in Shanghai, and took action to begin the necessarily long process of putting in place the physical infrastructure and institutional capacity for adequate wastewater management. In 1986, SMG completed a study identifying an optimal wastewater management strategy for the city, comprising a two-phased investment program of combined wastewater collection systems, to be managed by a financially sustainable urban wastewater utility which would charge for services. Phase I of the investment program covered 1987-95; Phase II includes three stages of works (1996-98, 1999-2006, and 2007-2010) to accommodate flows up to the year 2020. 2.8 The strategy also calls for: (a) conveying wastewater to the Changjiang rather than to the Huangpu, which now has very limited assimilative capacity; (b) phasing out the nightsoil and septic tank systems; (c) reducing the water volumes extracted by
 - 8 - industries from the Huangpu, with consequent reductions in wastewater discharges. The latter would be achieved by reorienting industries from "end-of-pipe" treatment to a "clean technology" approach. In the latter connection, industries would be encouraged to keep cooling water streams (which tend to be warmer than intake water) separate from other waters, and recycle water where possible; (d) continuing use of combined sewerage and stormwater systems where they already exist but switching to separate systems where feasible such as when new construction is being undertaken, as in Pudong; (e) providing treatment before discharge to the Changjiang in order to limit the total phosphorus discharged to less than 18 tons/day; and (f) phasing out existing small municipal treatment plants when they become obsolete and conveying the flows to the Changjiang. 2.9 With Bank assistance under the previous and proposed sewerage projects, SMG is pursuing that strategy, which has been validated by subsequent technical analysis factoring in the impact of more recent developments. The ultimate environmental objective of these projects is to raise the quality of water in both the network of city canals and the Huangpu River. Canal water, now failing to reach even the lowest level needed for productive use, would be raised to no lower than Category IV quality, suitable for fishery, industrial and agricultural use. Water quality in the Huangpu, which in its lower reach now falls below a level suitable for industrial use, would be raised to Category IIT, suitable as a raw water source for municipal treatment plants. This very significant improvement is critical to the health of the city's people and to the vitality of its economy. System Facilities 2.10 The Conveyance System. Shanghai's sewerage system currently collects about 48 percent [or 2.6 million (M) m3/day] of total wastewater flows of 5.4 Mm3/day, with the remainder discharged directly into the city canals or the Huangpu. Prior to the commissioning in 1993 of the main interceptor constructed under SSPI, only about 1.2 Mm 3/day was collected. SSPI works were concentrated in the city's northern section. 2.11 Collected wastewater is discharged as follows: 700,000 m3/day flows to the Changjiang via the western interceptor at Shidonkou; 500,000 m3/day flows to the East China Sea via the southern interceptor at Bailonggang; and 1.4 Mm3/day flows to the Changjiang via the Zhuyuan interceptor constructed under the first sewerage project. The Changjiang's assimilative capacity at Zhuyuan ensures no adverse effect to downstream users. Recent studies have confirmed that discharge of wastewater from Shanghai to the Huangpu River is no longer sustainable in terms of either the River's assimilative capacity or, most importantly, its role as the primary source of potable water for the city. All wastewater is therefore being conveyed to the Changjiang estuary where, after treatment (pretreatment or, in the medium term, primary treatment to remove phosphorus, thereby minimizing eutrophication), the effluent is discharged through submerged ocean outfalls and diffuser systems.
 - 9 - 2.12 The second phase of the conveyance system to be constructed under the proposed project would serve the rapidly developing Pudong and Puxi areas in the southern part of the city, covering some 240 km2. The system would be designed to handle 1.7 Mm3/day and be sized to capture projected flows of 5.0 Mm3/day in the year 2020. The flows would be discharged through a submerged outfall to the Changjiang at Bailonggang, some 25 km downstream of Zhuyuan. Extensive modeling of the Bailonggang area has confirmed that the Changjiang has sufficient assimilative capacity, and that the environmental impact of the discharges at Bailonggang and in the adjacent Hangzhou Bay would be acceptable. 2.13 Treatment Facilities. Less than two thirds of the wastewater collected receives any form of treatment, most of that being restricted mainly to pretreatment of industrial wastes, or through septic tanks from which the effluents are discharged into nearby waterways. The 12 existing treatment plants, most handling no more than 40,000 m3/day, operate at less than half their design capacity and handle about 3 percent of Shanghai's average dry- weather flows, usually at the secondary treatment level. 2.14 The proposed project would rehabilitate the systems and facilities associated with three existing treatment plants of about 255,000 m3/day total capacity at Quyang, Tianshan and Longhua. As mentioned above, studies indicate that discharges at Bailonggang from the proposed project's conveyor system would require only preliminary treatment (screening and grit removal) in the medium term. However, land has been allocated for the future construction of a chemically-assisted primary wastewater treatment plan, with an initial capacity of about 0.86 Mm /day. Engineering studies for the treatment plant are underway, ensuring that the plant could be constructed in stages as pollution loads and flows increase over time, commencing in about the year 2000. The environmental objective would be to ensure that phosphorus levels discharged do not cause eutrophication in the vicinity, and that dissolved oxygen levels do not endanger marine life. This phased strategy is the least-cost approach to environmental management. Institutional Development 2.15 Shanghai's strategy for wastewater management includes phased strengthening of the Shanghai Municipal Sewerage Company, Ltd. (SMSC) in parallel with physical development of the system. SMSC was preceded by the Shanghai Sewerage Company (SSC), which was established in 1987 under SSPI. SSC benefited from training under that project but its organization required adjustment to allow effective management of the expanding system needs; this led SMG to form SMSC (para. 4.1), absorbing SSC and allocating enlarged responsibilities to the new organization. Based on an organizational study carried out under the earlier project, SMSC has prepared an action plan for its reorganization and further strengthening, which it would carry out with technical assistance to be provided under the proposed project. The plan includes a focus on furthering the company's commercialization by improving financial and accounting capabilities. Details of SMSC's institutional objectives are given in Chapter 4.
 - 10- Financial Strategy 2.16 Achieving financial sustainability of the wastewater system is critical to adequate operation and maintenance of existing facilities and to the system expansion required to support Shanghai's continued growth. SSPI introduced tariffs that now meet operating and maintenance expenses (excluding depreciation). However, with only marginal tariff increases during 1993-95 but wage and administrative cost increases of about 55 percent and 46 percent a year, respectively, SSC had to rely on government transfers- construction taxes and public utility levies (principally on water supply)-to meet stormwater drainage and debt service costs. Recently, SMG signaled its intention to press on towards making the system financially self-sustaining by approving substantially increased wastewater tariffs in July 1995, which are scheduled for implementation from March 1996. To meet Shanghai's financial targets for SMSC under the project would require further tariff adjustments which, if implemented, would ensure continued development of SMSC's financial capacity. SMSC's current and projected financial performance is discussed further in Chapter 5. D. WASTEWATER FLOWS AND POLLUTION LOADS 2.17 Wastewater flows and pollution loads to be handled by Shanghai's sewerage system have been estimated based on parameters described in the following paragraphs. Water Consumption and Wastewater Projections 2.18 Per capita water consumption in Shanghai rose from 79 liters per capita per day (l/c/d) in 1984 to 118 l/c/d in 1992, which is considered reasonable for a wealthy city like Shanghai. Average consumption by the year 2000 is expected to reach 160 I/c/d with higher personal incomes, increasing use of water-consuming appliances, and the gradual change from bucket latrines to flush toilets. However, the past growth rate of 6.0 percent will likely slow to 2.5 to 3.5 percent by the year 2000, in response to water pricing policy changes introduced as part of the ongoing SEP that are geared to providing a positive rate of return on revalued assets. Higher water charges should blunt demand and consequently reduce wastewater flows. Per capita consumption levels are therefore expected to rise from their year 2000 level to 225 l/c/d in 2010 and 280 l/c/d in 2020. These growth rates are considered reasonable, given the current rate of economic growth. 2.19 Total wastewater flows in SMSC's service area now total about 5.5 million (M) m 3/day (average dry weather flow). This includes 0.6 Mm3/d (11 percent) of wastewater that is treated and discharged to local watercourses, 2.6 Mm3/d (48 percent of wastewater conveyed and discharged to the Changjiang Estuary (without treatment), and 2.2 Mm3/d (41 percent) of wastewater discharged to local watercourses without treatment. Projections of wastewater flows show increases to 6.0 Mm3/d, 6.9 Mm3/d and 7.8 Mm3/d in the years 2000, 2010 and 2020, respectively. Estimates are based on water supply projections and include groundwater infiltration (estimated at 2,000 m3/d/km' in the Puxi area and 1,000 m 3d/km in Pudong). Wastewater projections are shown in Annex 2.
 Pollution Loads 2.20 Industry currently accounts for, and is projected to remain at, approximately 50 percent of the total wastewater flow in Shanghai in the year 2000. The pollution loads, in terms of biological oxygen demand (BOD), chemical oxygen demand (COD), ammonia and phosphorus, however, are dominated by those of domestic wastewater and the significance of industry is much lower, accounting for 30 percent or less of the total loads. This can be attributed to the particularly low strength of industrial wastewater as a result of excessive water consumption per unit of output, and to the predominance of industries based on inorganic materials, therefore discharging little if any organic matter in wastewater. 2.21 Quantities of industrial wastewater are expected to decline initially, mainly as a result of process improvements and moves to more water-efficient technology, and rise slowly thereafter as a result of sustained growth in industrial output. However, the growth in domestic loads consequent upon the phasing out of nightsoil and septic tank systems will mean that the relative significance of industrial pollution loads will not increase. 2.22 There are, however, a number of toxic and sparingly degradable substances of industrial origin in Shanghai's wastewater. The principal substances include heavy metals such as arsenic, copper, mercury, lead and zinc, cyanide and phenol. 2.23 The impact of the overall loads of BOD, COD, phosphorus and ammonia in the context of the assimilative capacity of the Changjiang Estuary is limited (a "footprint" of under 1 km2), particularly in the immediate term. Extensive modeling studies have shown that predicted pollution loads up to the year 2000 can be fully assimilated; beyond that time, manageable amounts of phosphorus should be removed as flows and loads increase. This has been carefully analyzed during preparation of the Environmental Assessment. It is proposed, therefore, to adopt a strict control policy for toxic substances, based largely on control at source, but to adopt a total load approach in respect of organic pollutants such as BOD. As mentioned above (para. 2.14), phosphorus is the limiting pollutant, and phosphorus control would be the objective of the management strategy. Pollution load projections are shown in Annex 2, and further background provided in Annex 9. 2.24 As indicated previously, wastewater pretreatment facilities would be provided for in the proposed project, and land would be reserved and provision made in the system design for the future construction of further treatment as pollution loads increase. Phase I investments under SSPI were designed to remove about 20 percent of the total urban pollution load in the Huangpu, and Phase II investments under the proposed project would aim to collect parts of the remaining loads. The rationale for this approach in terms of compliance with discharge standards is discussed in detail in Annex 9.

LESSONS LEARNED 2.25 There are three principal lessons learned from our lending in Shanghai and elsewhere that have been incorporated into the project: (a) provision and management of financially sustainable urban environmental services; (b) effective environmental management and pollution control; and (c) the need for rigorous project preparation and careful implementation. 2.26 Provision and Management of Urban Environmental Services. The Operations Evaluation Department review of Bank water and sanitation projects (Water Supply and Sanitation Projects: The Bank Experience 1967-1989), concluded that to meet borrower and Bank development objectives, project design should incorporate institution building, financial viability, and poverty alleviation as core conceptual elements. Bank municipal management sector work in connection with incentives for urban service delivery emphasizes the need to properly assign functional responsibilities and link revenue to expenditures. In China, environmental services are provided at the municipal level, where a high percentage of government revenue is also captured. Recent sector work (China. Urban Environmental Service Management) concluded that the major failing in environmental services has been dependence on municipal budget transfers to fund services, while greater reliance on user charges would be affordable, induce resource conservation, and create a more dependable income stream. Increasing tariffs has therefore been a focal point of our policy dialogue. Under the first Sewerage Project, a conflict arose between SMG's desire to protect SSC's financial viability and the political pressure on SMG to limit tariff increases in an inflationary environment. Discussions during preparation of the proposed project highlighted the need for a resolution of this conflict, and SMG approved a tariff increase in consequence prior to appraisal for implementation commencing in 1996. This aspect of the project would be a focal point for dialogue during implementation. 2.27 Effective Environmental Management and Pollution Control. Reviewing recent Bank experience in pollution control including projects in China, Asia, Latin America and Africa has highlighted the importance of facilitating the means for all polluters to connect to wastewater systems, thereby expanding system coverage and the numbers of paying consumers, and ensuring the cost-effective capture of all polluting wastewaters. The project design draws on these lessons and those in the two recent sector studies (China: Environmental Strategy Paper and China: Urban Environmental Service Management). The latter stresses issues of political commitment especially with respect to pricing matters, appropriate environmental standards and management incntives, and monitoring and enforcement capabilities. This project also addresses those issues through an action plan to enhance system connections, and strengthen wastewater utility management. The ongoing Shanghai Environment Project includes important supporting initiatives under implementation, which provide in-plant water pollution reduction and treatment of the 33 major polluting industries (some 80 percent of the total industrial wastewater pollution in Shanghai), implemented through an ongoing time- bound Action Plan.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION 6.1 Some 52 percent of Shanghai's average daily wastewater flow of 65 m3/sec discharges directly into the network of canals in the city, or to the Huangpu River that bisects Shanghai. As a result, canal water quality typically fails to reach the lowest level needed for productive use and in its downstream reach the Huangpu quality falls below the level deemed suitable for industrial use. Although raw water supplies for municipal use would be protected through relocation of the main intake, emergency raw water abstraction points and industrial abstraction continue at risk of either extraordinary treatment demands or sheer unusability. The continued use of surface waters for clothes washing and small boat travel expose people to unacceptable health risks and the fishery industry has been destroyed by pollution. Other losses include amenity value. Significant improvements in the management of wastewater and nightsoil systems, achieved through the project's investments, would raise these waters to no lower than Category IV, suitable for fishery, industrial and agricultural use, and ultimately the Huangpu itself to Category III, suitable as a raw water source for municipal treatment plants. This annex describes the likely land acquisition and resettlement impacts under the Second Shanghai Sewerage Project (SSPII) and discusses the framework developed by the Shanghai Municipal Government (SMG) for implementation of land acquisition and resettlement activities. Section B describes the impacts of the project and the surveys carried out to measure them. Section C discusses the elements of the resettlement implementation framework. The major portion of the project would be in the Pudong new area, the suburban and rural area on the outskirts of Shanghai. The implementation of the project is proposed to commence in April 1996 and would continue up to June 2001. B. PROJECT IMPACTS 2. Project components requiring land acquisition are the following: (a) Interceptor in Puxi; (b) Interceptor in Pudong; (c) Two siphons under the Huangpu river (Wujing/Minhang and Puxi to Pudong); (d) Four pumping stations; and (e) Treatment plant and outfall at Bailonggang. 3. Construction of the above-mentioned components of the project would require land acquisition and resettlement/rehabilitation of people affected by the project. In order to determine the impact of the project on affected people and properties, Shanghai Sewerage Project Construction Company (SSPCC) conducted two surveys: (a) Census survey of affected persons and properties; and (b) Socioeconomic survey of affected persons 4. The census survey of affected persons and properties was carried out from March 1-31, 1995 by SSPCC in collaboration with the local governments and the
 - 72 - ANNEX8 representatives of the affected people. The surveys were carried out on the basis of the engineering designs available as of March 31, 1995. There may be some minor modifications in the engineering designs that would be the basis of the final census surveys to be carried out sufficiently before implementation of land acquisition and resettlement activities. The following impacts were identified in the census surveys: (a) the total amount of land to be acquired is approximately 188 ha; (b) approximately 114 ha of land would be required temporarily during construction; (c) a total of 1,092 houses with an area of 147,250 m2 would be relocated; (d) 173 enterprises would be affected by the project, out of which 21 would need to be relocated while the rest can be reorganized at the same location after construction; (e) the total number of persons affected by land acquisition andlor resettlement is 7,426. Out of these, 1,516 are affected both by land acquisition and house relocation. A total of 4,924 and 4,018 persons are affected by land acquisition and resettlement alone, respectively; (f) there are 2,143 persons within the working age out of the 4,924 affected by land acquisition; (g) 671 persons would be eligible for payment of old-age pension and other special rehabilitation measures; (h) 30,091 workers, working in 173 enterprises affected by the project would also be affected. Some 2,391 workers, working in the 21 enterprises to be relocated, would be affected until the enterprises are reconstructed. The remaining 27,700 workers would be affected only during the construction period and would continue to work at the enterprises at the same location. 5. The socioeconomic survey of affected people was carried out by the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences (SASS) in May 1995 to identify the main socioeconomic impacts of the project on the affected people. The survey results stress the need to pay adequate, replacement levels of compensation to affected people and the need for timely provision of new jobs. The affected people are in support of the project and wanted timely and adequate compensation and resettlementlrehabilitation arrangements. SASS would conduct detailed baseline socioeconomic surveys of the affected persons in each contract before the initiation of land acquisition and resettlement activities on the respective contract of the project. The baseline survey would measure the income levels and standards of living of the affected persons before land acquisition and resettlement. This baseline socioeconomic survey would form the basis for future comparison of their income levels and standards of living as reported by the monitoring reports. Discussions were also held by the above agencies with World Bank missions. The design and alignment of the interceptor was modified at a nurnber of locations to avoid or reduce the impacts of land acquisition. FRAMEWORK FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT ACTIVITIES 7. The framework for implementation of land acquisition and resettlement program was set out by SSPCC in the Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) dated July 1995. Following the merger of SSPCC with the Shanghai Sewerage Company in November 1995, the new company-the Shanghai Municipal Sewerage Company, Ltd. (SMSC)- would have responsibility for implementation of the RAP (para. 16). The framework consists of the following: (a) Objectives and Principles of Resettlement; (b) Legal framework and resettlement policies; (c) Provisions for Job Creation; (d) Resettlement Institutions and agencies; (e) Costs and Budget; (f) Implementation schedule and arrangements for resettlement; (g) Participation and Consultations; (h) Redressal of grievances and the appeals process; and (i) Monitoring and Evaluation of Resettlement. The RAP, covering the above components of resettlement implementation framework, was prepared by SSPCC based on discussions held with various Bank preparation missions and the experience gained by SSPCC through implementation of the First Shanghai Sewerage Project (SSPI). These components of the framework for implementation are described below: Objectives and Principles of Resettlement 8. The main objective of the land acquisition and resettlement (LAR) program is to ensure that the standards of living and income levels of all categories of affected persons are improved, or at least restored after resettlement. The main principles on the basis of which the LAR program would be implemented are as follows: (a) Minimize resettlement as much as possible through changes in design and alignment; (b) Compensation for all structures would be paid at the replacement value of these structures; (c) Compensation for collective land would be paid to local collectives. This compensation would be used to increase the productive capacity of the collectives and would not be used for any other purpose;
 - 74 - ANNEX8 (d) Persons whose lands are affected would be provided jobs in nonagricultural enterprises. They would be paid a transition allowance until jobs are provided. Apart from payment of old-age pension, special rehabilitation measures would be taken to ensure that the elderly affected persons are able to restore their standards of living; (e) The new houses of the affected persons would be of at least the same standards as the affected houses or equal to the minimum current standard, whichever is more; (f) All affected civic infrastructure would be replaced at project cost; (g) All affected enterprises would be assisted to resume operations at nearby locations provided by the local governments. Workers would be provided allowances equivalent to their salaries for the period of closure of their enterprises; (h) Planning and implementation of LAR program would be carried out with the participation of affected persons and their representatives; and (i) The affected persons/enterprises would be able to redress their grievances, if any, from the LAR program, and if they are not satisfied, can appeal to higher authorities and courts. Shanghai is the largest and most heavily industrialized conurbation in China, producing about 11 percent of national industrial output. The City lies in a convergence zone of cold, dry and warm, humid air masses. Rainfall patterns are influenced both by monsoons and temperate cyclones. There are well- defined seasons with average monthly temperatures ranging from 3.4C in January to 27.2C in August. Annual average rainfall is 1,148 mm with a pronounced rainy season from June to September. The prevailing wind is northwesterly in winter and southeasterly in summer. 10. The Changjiang is the longest and largest river in China and the fourth largest in the world in terms of flow. The river rises on the border with Tibet, and its total catchment area of 1.8 million km2 covers approximately 19 percent of the total land area of China. It traverses a total of approximately 6,300 river km before discharging to the East China Sea to the east of Shanghai. The mean net downstream flow in the Changjiang at its most downstream gauging station at Datong (550 km upstream of the confluence with the Huangpu) is approximately 30,000 m3/s, with typical dry season flows in the range of 10,000 to 15,000 m3/s and wet season flows in excess of 50,000 m3/s. On an annual average basis the tidal inflow at the river mouth could be approximately 266,000 m3/s, almost nine times the average river flow. The inflow on a spring tide could be of the order 3 of 5 billion m3. 11. The river Huangpu flows through the Shanghai municipal area, flowing into the Changjiang at Wusongkou some 18 km to the north of the city. Flows in the Huangpu are measured at the gauging station at Mishidu, about 70 km upstream of the confluence with the Changjiang. The river is tidal at Mishidu and the mean net downstream flow is approximately 340 m3/s, about 1 percent of that in the Changjiang. Under extreme conditions of low natural flow in the Huangpu and peak tidal influence from the Changjiang, there can be net upward flows at Mishidu for periods of up to several days. 12. Water quality in the Changjiang upstream of the confluence with the Huangpu is generally good, although poorer at Bailonggang, which is downstream of the Huangpu confluence and is also affected by existing wastewater discharges at the shoreline. The Changjiang carries very substantial quantities of silt, with suspended solids concentrations exceeding 500 mg/I on average and annual silt loads of the order of 500 million tons. In the estuary the silt is mainly fine sand and clay, which has a strong adsorption capacity for a range of pollutants, particularly heavy metals. 13. All sources of the Huangpu are generally of good quality, but water quality in the Huangpu declines as it traverses the Shanghai Municipality area as a result of discharges of domestic and industrial wastewater and runoff from agricultural areas. Water quality problems are exacerbated under conditions of low natural flow in the Huangpu, when the tidal influence of the Changjiang causes extensive upstream movement of pollution from the lower reaches of the river.

The assumptions made when calculating the projections of the on-budget revenue and expenditure statements of the Shanghai Municipal Government (SMG) for the period 1994-2002 are set out below. On-budget revenues are those arising from taxes levied on enterprises operating in the Shanghai Municipal area; off-budget revenues consist of special fees to enterprises and are used chiefly for capital expenditures. Revenue Forecast 2. The actual (1990-94) on-budget revenue figures have been derived from data provided by SMG. Between 1990 and 1993, the average annual increase in revenue was about 15.5 percent. In 1994, however, the Central Government restructured the tax system, bolstering its share. As a result, there was a 28 percent decline in revenue in 1994 from 1993. To estimate future revenues, a conservative estimate of an average annual increase of 10 percent in nominal terms has been assumed using 1994 as the base year. Expenditure Forecast 3. Historically, on-budget expenditures have represented about 50 percent of on- budget revenues. In 1994, however, they jumped to 110 percent of that year's revenue as the tax system was restructured (para. 2). No adjustment was made to the expenditure program. To estimate future expenditures, the ratio of expenditures to revenues is assumed to decline to about 80 percent of revenues in 1995; 68 percent in 1996; and 58 percent thereafter. 4. The threat manifests itself in almost all areas of the country, but is particularly acute in large urban areas, where the concentration of population and economic activity has led more rapidly to an overloading of the absorptive capacity of the environment. In response, the Bank has formulated an urban environmental lending strategy that uses price-driven incentives to reduce effluents and pay for their handling and treatment, while also assisting in the long-neglected task of providing a physical infrastructure that can provide services and manage pollution in the most cost-effective manner. 2. The choice to work in Shanghai follows directly from the Bank's strategy. As the largest and most developed urban area of China, Shanghai has long served as a model for China's urban and industrial development. Shanghai has the oldest industrial base of all Chinese cities, but the pressure to remit a very high percentage of profits to the national government has until very recently seriously constrained Shanghai's ability to invest in social infrastructure. By the early 1980s, that underinvestment had resulted in rapidly increasing transportation costs over an antiquated road network; in industrial effluent discharges far exceeding national standards, often discharged directly into waterways used for industrial and drinking water supply; in uncontrolled hazardous waste disposal; and in solid waste disposal into landfills with no provision for leachate control. Little attention had been given to systematic evaluation of these problems either singly or, most importantly, in their cumulative impact. 3. Since 1984 the Bank has been working with Shanghai to address this range of problems. Transportation constraints are being eased through Shanghai Metropolitan Transport Projects I and II (Credit 2296 and Loan 3652), which finance transportation planning, improved traffic management, and investment in key urban roads. The first step in the long-term program to end the direct discharge of effluents into municipal waters, the Shanghai Sewerage Project-SSPI (Loan 2794/Credit 1779), captures the waste- and stormwater discharges in downtown Shanghai for preliminary treatment and disposal through an outfall on the Yangtze, relieving pressure on the most highly polluted waters in the urban core of the municipality. The Shanghai Environment Project-SEP (Loan 3711) addresses a wide array of problems, including that of a safe source for the city water supply, improved solid waste handling, and the sewering of a major industrial district. However, additional works come on line much more slowly under the low growth scenario, leading to increasingly large savings over time. Almost all housing in urban Shanghai is served by 24-hour piped water, with only 1 percent of the population now relying on standpipes for water supply. Therefore, because wastewater tariffs are derived from piped water usage for domestic users, even the poorest segments of the community would face the higher domestic tariffs proposed to finance the project. Based on an averaged wastewater tariff of Y 0.40 proposed above, the expected tariff increase would raise the effective cost of water and wastewater services from the current Y 0.51 level to Y 0.91 per m3, and the combined water/wastewater bill for families in the poorest 10 percent of the population would increase to about Y 12/month (assuming a water consumption of about 13 m3/month/liousehold), or 1.5 percent of their incomes. If the poorest 10 percent continue to share in real income growth, as they generally have in recent years, these cost of living increases can be easily covered. For the very poorest 0.5 percent, real incomes have not kept pace with social averages. This group would need their social welfare payments augmented to meet these additional costs. 42. SMSC's consultants conducted a willingness-to-pay for wastewater services study. The study was worded to elicit the broadest measure of willingness-to-pay for a healthier water regime, rather than to evaluate response to the current project proposal. As such, the findings could be interpreted as an upper bound to willingness-to-pay for the current project. The results were consistent with international experience. T he average willingness-to-pay was Y 1.30 per month. This contrasts unfavorably with the Y 4.20 per month that would be required of the average family, if they do not adjust their consumption when wastewater costs rise. The difference between the willingness-to-pay and the needed tariff can be interpreted as a tax on the user to cover the negative externalities generated bv their wastewater discharges.

doc.abstracts: The Second Shanghai Sewerage Project is part of the next phase of Shanghai Municipality's development program to improve environmental conditions and management. The overriding project objective is to provide a safe environmental setting for the long-term growth of Shanghai, enabling sustained economic and industrial growth. Specific objectives of the project are to: 1) enhance wastewater and stormwater management through expanding wastewater collection, pretreatment and disposal capacity and stormwater drainage facilities; 2) reduce urban pollution impact, while facilitating pollution control; 3) improve wastewater utility financial and operational management; and 4) strengthen sector institutions through training, feasibility studies, and future investment project preparation in the environment area. The project will comprise: 1) financial and policy initiatives, planning, institutional and management reforms; and 2) an investment program of environmentally-oriented capital works and institutional measures to support management and operational capacity-building of Shanghai Municipal Sewerage Company Ltd. The investment program will consist of the following components: (a) sewerage and sanitation improvements; (b) wastewater treatment and disposal systems; and (c) institutional development and training.
